verses.text: O Lord, the king rejoices in Your strength; how greatly he celebrates Your deliverance!
verses.comment: This verse praises God as the source of victory and salvation. The king's joy points to recognition that all deliverance comes from God, prefiguring the ultimate King, Christ, who rejoices in the Father’s will (see Luke 10:21).

verses.text: You have given him his heart’s desire and have not withheld the request of his lips. Selah.
verses.comment: "Selah" invites meditation. God responds generously to the prayers of the king, foreshadowing Christ whose prayers were always heard (John 11:42). There is a sense of divine favor granted to the anointed one.

verses.text: You come to meet him with rich blessings; upon his head You place a crown of pure gold.
verses.comment: The "crown of pure gold" symbolizes divine approval and kingship. In a spiritual sense, this anticipates the crowning of Christ with glory (Heb 2:9).

verses.text: He asked You for life, and You gave it to him—length of days forever and ever.
verses.comment: The 'length of days forever and ever' suggests eternal life. While David lived out his years, this ultimately points to the Messiah’s unending reign (Luke 1:33).

verses.text: His glory is great through Your salvation; You have bestowed on him splendor and majesty.
verses.comment: The king’s dignity comes from salvation given by God. This connects to the glorification of Christ after His passion (Phil 2:9-11), showing both the honor given to the anointed king and foreshadowing of the exalted Lord.

verses.text: For You make him most blessed forever; You make him glad with the joy of Your presence.
verses.comment: To be ‘blessed forever’ is both a royal and messianic promise (Isaiah 9:7). True joy is found in God’s presence, connecting with the experience of saints united with God eternally.

verses.text: For the king trusts in the Lord; through the steadfast love of the Most High, he will not be shaken.
verses.comment: Security for God’s king comes from trust in God’s faithful love. This points to Jesus’ confidence in the Father during His earthly ministry (Heb 5:7).

verses.text: Your hand will find all Your enemies; Your right hand will seize those who hate You.
verses.comment: God’s power extends over all the king’s enemies. This verse foreshadows the final judgment, when all opposition to God is defeated (Rev 19:15).

verses.text: You will make them like a blazing oven at the time of Your appearing. The Lord will swallow them up in His wrath, and fire will consume them.
verses.comment: The imagery of fiery judgment is common for God’s enemies. This has eschatological overtones and is echoed in Jesus’ parables about the last judgment.

verses.text: You will destroy their offspring from the earth, and their descendants from among the children of men.
verses.comment: Annihilation of enemies’ posterity signifies total defeat. In the spiritual sense, evil and its legacy will not endure in God’s kingdom (see Malachi 4:1).

verses.text: Though they intend evil against You and devise wicked plans, they cannot succeed.
verses.comment: Human plotting against God is ultimately futile. This is seen in the Passion, when attempts to destroy Jesus result instead in salvation for the world (Acts 2:23-24).

verses.text: For You will put them to flight; You will aim at their faces with Your bow.
verses.comment: God’s swift judgment is pictured by the archer’s skill. The theme of divine justice reminds believers of the need for repentance and trust in God’s mercy.

verses.text: Be exalted, O Lord, in Your strength! We will sing and praise Your power.
verses.comment: The psalm closes in doxology, focusing worship on God’s power and exaltation, a theme picked up in the New Testament’s worship of Christ, the victorious King (Phil 2:11; Rev 5:12-13).
